review_title: Great profs to work with, limited opportunities available

- Profs are readily available and open to meaningful discussions

cons:
- Admin can be very slow, limiting, and restrictive
- Small size of labs make it hard for larger collaborative research
- Fewer number of profs limit the variety of research available

pros: The YNC Admissions Office was a fantastic place to work at because the team was always willing to cover for each other, I had good direct leadership and it felt like we were contributing towards the overall growth of the college. YNC will certainly be missed.

review_title: swift handling of the Covid-19 situation
pros:
Clean beautiful safe environment.

The administrative supports are overall very good.
cons:
There is not much space for serendipity due to the pandemic.
I am not sure how seriously meritocracy is practiced. It seems better than most institutes in Europe and US. But I am less certain when comparing Yale-NUS College with other institutes in Singapore.

pros: A truly diverse and inclusive community that encourages autonomy and values opinions.

review_title: Exciting Professional Environment With Room For Personal Development
pros: Yale-NUS College is a unique opportunity in that it is a very selective higher education institution, but there is still ample space for new hires to join and shape the institution. The opportunity to work in such a multi-cultural office space and have a vision for higher education that is leading edge is something you can not find almost anywhere else in the industry. If you are mission based and share the strategic goals of the institution it is easy to jump 100% and work for the good of the community and institution.
cons: As with any new institution the opportunity to shape and develop policy and projects abound. If you are simply looking to do the minimum or are not excited by working with a moral mission in mind, then this may not be the place for you. As the community feels as though it is working for global change and to support the students the work ethic pushes many beyond the average standard of work. It is a wonderful experience, but something to be aware of for those who are not looking to devote beyond the standard 9 to 5.

pros: International faculties, Green campus, Part of NUS
cons: Slow administration, poor infrastructure and resources for research labs

review_title: Overall an Incredible Place to Teach
job_title: Assistant Professor in Clementi New Town,
pros:
- Brilliant students. On par with the Ivy Leagues,  but harder-working and much more international
- Good work atmosphere with friendly colleagues
- Excellent salary. It's more generous than all but the most prestigious institutions North America
- Low teaching load with regular sabbaticals
- A good amount of support for research
- An admirable mission. Combining Eastern and Western traditions in the Common Curriculum is pretty unique, for example
- Faculty housing for non-Singaporean faculty is close to work and heavily subsidized. Combined with the salary, it's very easy to work at Yale-NUS and save money
cons:
- Too much turnover in upper administration, though hopefully this is in the past
- Uncertainty about tenure standards. This is perhaps to be expected since Yale-NUS is a new institution, but it's still a con

review_title: A dynamic and vibrant working environment with great work-life balance!
pros:
The college is highly selective in their hiring process and ensure only the best of the best make through into the organization!

Excellent brand name and reputation

Work closely with high calibre individuals from diverse backgrounds

Good opportunity to grow and learn with very supportive colleagues 

Excellent facilities and services available to all staff members

Comprehensive leave and medical benefits scheme 

Good work-life balance
cons: Nothing too serious to complain about really!

pros: Relaxed and friendly work environment, easy to communicate with other departments. Had a good boss but she left. Good work life balance.  Opportunity to travel for conferences and management supportive of staff going for training courses.
cons: Less priority for staff development as most resources channeled towards faculty and students. Lack of direction and guidance from senior management. Small department, less opportunity for progression. Spend too much time and resources developing own systems and policies that are different from NUS.

pros:
I worked as a Student Associate for multiple departments - as a Senior Associate I earned $12/hour which was pretty good pay for on an campus job. 

The work environment and superiors were excellent and I learned a lot.
cons: All payments have to go through a lot of bureaucracy to get approved, so there is a lag time in payment.

pros: International environment. Open culture, not rigid as per Singaporean culture. Bureaucracy is present, but senior management is generally accessible and approachable. Work-life balance is encouraged.
cons: Policies ever-changing and can be quite loose, given that campus is new and a lot of policies are based on trial and error. Can be challenging in areas of operations of the school.

pros: Good pay. Teachers do either form teacher ship or CCA. Students are rather homogenous to teach. Teachers teach 15hrs a week, may need to do research work.
cons: Lack of exposure to professional development. Lagging in practices compared to mainstream schools. Lessons stretch to 6pm.

pros: away from CBD area and cheaper food in canteen. Nothing much i could think of.
cons: Management is very resistant to change. They find it hard to make decisions. Also, they are very unappreciative of their own staff, making employees feel dispensable. There is little empowerment of staff and consequently a lot of micro-managing. Management are quite short-sighted and do not have a clear vision for the future. Overall, employee satisfaction and happiness is low.

pros: Dynamic, energetic community of students and faculty
cons: Uncompetitive remuneration package and slow career progression (except for staff who knew how to manage upwards)

review_title: Worth experiencing but not for everyone

international, diverse, dynamic

review_title: Dynamic and exciting environment weighed down by unaddressed toxic work culture
pros:
- highly engaged student body
- well resourced financially
- space for creativity and innovation
- progressive and diverse relative to the local context
- aesthetically pleasing campus environment
- ample opportunity to make a mark or create new initiatives
cons:
- lack of transparency around promotions and career progressions
- gossip culture
- poor work/life balance 
- high turnover
- lack of psychological safety
- disempowered middle management
- little focus on mentorship and sustainable professional growth

pros: Great research opportunities, work-life balance.
cons: I can't think of any.

pros: Excellent environment to work on
cons: Can’t think of any cons

pros: Yale-NUS is a young college filled with interesting colleagues. People from around the world as well as around Asia are working together to build a new type of Asian college. It's inspiring and easy to feel like your work means a lot. Staff is great, benefits and compensation as well.
cons: Departments can feel a little distant from each other. Young college also means a heavy workload sometimes. You need to know yourself really well to decide if this particular set of challenges is what you want.

pros: Most people are very committed to their jobs and to the students, multinational-multicultural team - DO take this job if you have the opportunity
cons: Some employees feel overworked due to low staffing level, clash in management philosophy due to different departments' operational philosophies

pros: The salary is better than average. The  start up fund is better than average. The chance to majors in college is great.
cons: Work life balance can be difficult. Finding time for research can also be difficult.

pros: Small office environment so people work really closely with one another
cons: Since it is a small environment, you have a huge range of duties from high level to low level work which can be frustrating

review_title: A growing college with a liberal arts view of the world in Asia
pros: the unique learning environment embedded in a highly dynamic city
cons: they are still trying to figure out what they want

pros: People are friendly and the environment is great.
cons: A little bit unstructured and the workload can be heavy.
